A Title of Some Sort
by drew on February 04, 2016

Long live the PC

A popular narrative in the computing world for many years has been that the desktop PC is dead. There's some truth to that; it's certainly the case that mobile devices make up a large and growing proportion of computer use and that the sale of desktop PCs (which in this context includes laptops) has been in a slow decline for years.

It's a half-truth, though. PC sales have been in decline largely because computers last us longer — for numerous reasons the rapid increase in speeds and capacities began to slow about a decade ago and, as a result, there's less impetus to upgrade so often. And most mobile users are new users, people who did not previously do much, if any, computing.

There are certainly some for whom a mobile device has replaced a desktop PC or laptop but they are relatively few. Those of us for whom a computer is a work tool rather than just a communication device — those of us who make stuff — still need a PC and will for the foreseeable future. We can't get long-form writing, programming, photo editing, graphic design, music production, video editing or data analysis done on a tablet or smartphone.

Proprietary motivations

The primary concern of proprietary, commercial software vendors is not to make the best product they can, it's to make as much money as possible — a tech company that's not growing rapidly is seen as failing. Where competition exists this is fine; in a perfect world the superior product will sell the most. Unfortunately, in many realms of computing, there is no competition. Microsoft attained a 90% share of desktop operating systems in 1995 and have maintained a virtual monopoly ever since. Similar monopolies exist in graphical production with Adobe's Photoshop and Illustrator, in word processing and office work with Microsoft's Office products and in virtually every other area of computing.

When a software product is dominant, its authors no longer need to improve it — innovation is risky and R&D is extremely expensive and difficult to justify to shareholders. Instead they utilise lock-in, forced obsolescence and anti-competitive business practises to maintain their advantage.

Lock-in describes any practise designed to make switching to a competing product difficult. An example of this would be Microsoft's proprietary document formats which are not primarily designed to be good document formats, they're designed to be difficult for third party applications to read. If you wanted to view a .docx file then, until quite recently, you needed to use Microsoft Word.

And these formats change. The new version of Office will have a new version of .docx — it doesn't introduce new functionality, its purpose is to break compatibility with older versions. No matter how much you want to stick with the old Office, eventually someone will send you a newer document than your version can handle and you'll have to upgrade.

Anti-competitive business practises include a wide range of strategies, chief amongst which are simply buying up and shutting down the competition, using software patents to stifle competition and the "Embrace, Extend, Extinguish" approach.

Mobile and spying

Apple demonstrated with their iPhone quite how much money there was to be made with mobile devices. At the same time, Google were making huge profits harvesting users' data and selling it to advertisers. Microsoft, their business perceived as flagging despite their desktop dominance, were listening.

Windows 8 and later 10 are Microsoft's attempt to get into the mobile market. Intended as an operating system to work on both mobile devices and desktop PCs, Windows 8 & 10 represent what is known as 'convergence' — the idea that one user interface should be used on all devices and from-factors — an approach Apple are also adopting in recent versions of their own desktop operating system, OSX.

This leaves desktop PC users who need to get actual work done with an interface not really designed for them. We've gone beyond software vendors simply not improving their software to, from the perspective of a desktop user with work to do, its actually becoming worse.

Like Google, Facebook and others' online services, Windows 10 collects a great deal of data on its users. Exactly what is collected, to what purpose it might be put and who owns information collected about the user is far from clear — it's collected simply because it's valuable. The popular aphorism usually used to describe services like Facebook applies equally to recent proprietary operating systems: You are not the customer, you are the product.

The Snowden Revalations illustrated beyond any reasonable doubt that the US and UK governments (amongst others) are engaging in mass surveillance and collection of citizens' internet activities and communications, both meta-data and content, and that they are doing so with the help of all the major proprietary technology companies.

While many shrug this constant, pervasive surveillance off as an inevitable part of modern life — "if you've got nothing to hide then you've got nothing to fear" — for those who believe in the value of free expression and free thought, living in a virtual panopticon with its associated chilling effects must be a concern. Privacy matters not because we want to hide things but because intellectual freedom is necessary to real progress.

Freedom
